Corporate America, middle market companies, small businesses are okay. There's a lot of liquidity. There's not a huge order book so sales aren't growing dramatically. So we have slow, modest growth and you're starting to see it in our calculations. Some of what we're getting is market share gains. So remember we did Middle Market. We weren't doing Middle Market banking in California. Now we do. We weren't doing small business in California. Now we do because of the WaMu acquisition. So we are gaining share in some of our businesses through credit card, middle market, small business, IB's holding share.

Second question, not a lot of discussion about litigation reserves in your commentary today. Could you just comment broadly about, with the CIO matter, with upcoming whatever may happen with LIBOR etcetera, what you guys think about your litigation reserves at this point?

Yeah, so I think, last time I spoke about mortgage. We think it's kind of well – we've really done a good job there and it could change over time. We put away a lot of – we put a lot away from mortgage over time. This quarter, when you see the 10-Q, as you get to see the 10-Q, it will show litigation expenses of like $300 million. So we try to keep up with reserving for things we know about. This quarter of course we had some big ins and outs. It isn't like just one thing that happens.
Richard Ramsden.

Yeah, Jamie, can you just take us through what the process is for reapplication for the buyback. Do you have to resubmit a full CCAR? Are the assumptions going to be the same as what they were for the first one? And what a reasonable timetable for that is going to be?
We're going to be resubmitting in a week or two.
Yes.
And we're getting instructions about what that process is going to be.
Monday.

What kind of – whatever it is, we think we can accommodate it and get it done and resubmitted. And like I said, I hope that both the Board of Governors, and the board is doing its review so I can't tell you when the board is going to end its review. But I'm hopeful that the board review, and the capital plan, are done in such a way that by early in the fourth quarter we can buy back stock if we want.
Okay. And with the stock trading where it is, does this change your waterfall in terms of buyback versus dividend, i.e., a dividend increase next year versus a buyback?
I wrote in my Chairman's letter that at tangible book value I think our stock is a great buy.
Thanks.
Ed Najarian.
Richard's question was my question, so you've got it. Thank you.
Andrew Marquardt.
Thanks. Just on the GIIPS exposure again, you've previously talked about max losses, if all things fail of $3 billion after-tax. Is that still valid or is there a new number there?

The $3 billion was my estimate after tax. It was $5 billion pre-tax. I did it with my own methodologies. I said it was a bad outcome. It's not the worst outcome. If you said that Europe unraveled, the Euro falls apart, I think it could be worse than that. The IB just recently, IB is constantly looking at these for the company. So TSS does it. Their number recently would be more like $3 billion. We have a Euro command center. We've got a lot of – we know exactly what we are doing. If something goes wrong, we are prepared to deal with it. We don't have to necessarily have losses at all. The issue with Europe and the complexities with Europe are what contracts apply, how they apply, who leaves the Euro, what currency are you paid in, what does it do for losses in the country. So there are these complex things, but those numbers would still be rough estimates of a bad outcome, but not the worst outcome.

Thank you. And then separately in terms of your outlook slide, something that wasn't there was the real estate portfolio. It's still coming down 10% to 15%, you've said in the past $500 million drag NII on a year-over-year basis.
Yes.
Is that still valid for this year and maybe a similar amount next year, is that an ongoing issue?
You can assume at this pace, same change, same assumptions.
Thank you.
Mike Mayo.

Mike Cavanagh had a statement saying the level of scrutiny did not evolve commensurate with the increased complexity. He was referring to CIO, but I wonder if that statement could apply to the Firm as a whole. I mean on February 28 we were all here, eight hours of presentations, over 200 slides, no mention of CIO. And then we had the CIO event, a risk model that didn't capture the risk, a new risk model that wasn't accurately tested before. Some checks and balances that might've been possible with the investment bank seemed a little siloed. So I'm wondering if the Firm as a whole has reached some sort of tipping point when it comes to bigness or complexity that makes it more difficult to manage than in the past?
No.
Okay. What can you say to further reassure us? I mean, you know you're here in person, have you lost a step? Has the focus gone off?

I'm getting old. We have – Mike, this company is the same company that went through 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, assimilated Bear Stearns, bought WaMu and we had record earnings the last year. We had record earnings the year before. It's likely, if you look at your own estimates, we'll have record earnings this year, that we have gained market share in Investment Banking, in TSS and Asset Management, our Commercial Bank in Small Business and Middle Market. We are just not doing a great job in marketing the company, we are going to sit back some other time and make this a more attractive company for you all. We made a mistake. We completely disclosed the mistake. We have denuded ourselves in front of you. We are in better shape than we were before.

Our CIO is not a place we expected a mistake. We made the mistake and I can't prove a negative. So you all can ask me all day long, I cannot prove a negative. We believe we have got very good controls and very good people in place.
I mean you've gotten the results...
I mean look at the results by the way.

Yeah, I know. The results, if we did not have the details here, it would be okay, but we saw how the sausage is made and that just makes me wonder if I might get food poisoning sometime in the future? What would you say as you talk to a portfolio manager and you have 20 seconds to say why it won't happen again, what would you say to that portfolio manager?

Because we have very granular limits. We've got risk committees, credit committees, audit committees. We do try to do a very good job. I think it's silly for anyone in the business world to think you are not going to make mistakes. It is not possible in the real world. That's only possible in a fictional world. I just think the mistakes should be small and few and far between, this being an exception.
Chris Whalen.

Chris Whalen from Tangent Capital Partners. First, just quickly on the CIO, does the nature of these instruments, these over-the-counter instruments, make you reconsider whether or not all of the controls and risk management and everything else you are putting in place can be effective?

It's not the nature of the instruments. A lot of these things are traded on exchanges, most of the indexes you can go buy and sell in the marketplace easily. Most are on clearinghouses and if you still want to see, you can see them. So I think this portfolio became very big and very complex. That is true. It should never ever, ever have gotten that big and that complex. And on May 10, the first I said it was too big, it was un-vetted, it shouldn't have been done. It was illiquid. It was bad. We should've caught it earlier.
Right. But that's kind of my point. When you have an instrument that doesn't have a clear basis, and the basis may shift, the correlations may shift very quickly. Can you manage that risk?
That's true for all financial instruments.
Right. Three quick regulatory questions, on Basel, to what extent does the Volcker Rule implementation limit your ability to manage the AFS portfolio?

None at all. The AFS portfolio is held for sale. So it's mark-to-market in the equity account but not mark-to-market. We think you should be allowed to portfolio hedge. We are not going to do something like this again, but we think pure portfolio hedging is not necessarily a bad thing. So we all talk about Europe, one of the quick ways you want to go hedge Europe, right now you get on the phone and you can buy $1 billion of protection on European, 100 or 120 European credit names. That is a good thing if you want to protect yourselves from Europe. It's not that complex. So Volcker changes the future for a whole bunch of things. We will adapt to that, whatever that is.
On Basel III, how do you expect Basel III implementation to affect your mortgage business?

On a Basel III basis, it's not material. The real issue is the NPR on Basel I, and that is a work in progress, but all the numbers that you see there in the projections we have, just assume continued growth in the mortgage business. So we will get some benefit. That runoff portfolio is going to liberate a substantial amount of Basel III capital, and as a result RWA and as a result free up some capital.
Right.

As a business matter, we'll be fine with whatever the Basel III numbers are. It is a little complex. It does create other things about mezzanine pieces, how securitization is going to work, what's the FICO score? FICO at 660 would be very bad under Basel III. Everyone will have to modify their business plan because of Basel III. It won't change the mortgage – our ability to be in the mortgage business.
Last question, how do you feel about the extension of the FDIC transaction account guarantee program?
I'm not sure what you're talking about.
The extended coverage to non-interest bearing transactions, deposits from the crisis (1:29:57)?
I'm not going to comment on that.
Moshe Orenbuch.

Thanks. Doug had mentioned about the material weakness related to the CIO office. The comments about the resubmission of the CCAR and the timeframe into the early fourth quarter, does that contemplate resolving all of the regulatory inquiries that are ongoing in addition to the board? And do you anticipate orders coming out of it? How should we think about the news flow from that standpoint?

We are hopeful that when the board finishes the review, the regulators get to look at everything that Mike has said and done, ask their questions, file the CCAR. We're hopeful that by the first quarter we will be able to buy back stock. We think the numbers justify it. We think the performance of the company justifies it, but we want to go through that process. It's a prudent thing to do. If something stops that from happening, then so be it.
Thank you very much.
Brennan Hawken.

Brennan Hawken, UBS. I appreciate that you guys didn't include some of the synthetic gains in your estimates of earnings power, but it might help if when we're looking at these past CIO gains and net income, if we can know how much of that was attributed to the synthetic? So you've got $2 billion over 2007 to 2011. Clearly a portion of that is in that $9.2 billion from 2009 to 2011. Can we have – is most of that $2 billion there in the 2009 to 2011? Can you give us an idea there?
I think it was about $1.4 billion of $2 billion was in 2008 to 2010.
Was that pre-tax or after-tax?
Pre-tax.
It was pre-tax. Those numbers are after-tax that you're looking at.
Okay, so that's apples – all right, great. And then do you know if with the CCAR resubmission is the scenario going to change? Or is it going to be the same?
They are refreshing and updating their scenarios. We're going to run a new scenario pursuant to their guidelines.
Okay. And the discussions, I would assume, Jamie, your confidence that 4Q can get it started, that is reflective of what you've heard back from the Fed as well?
What I said is we are hopeful and I've been wrong before.

Fair enough. And then my last one, I don't know if you can comment on this, but it would be helpful to know, do you guys have specific controls that separate communications between derivatives traders and the LIBOR rate submission employees?
We're not going to comment on anything like that right now.
Okay. Thanks.
Ed Najarian.

Yeah, a question for Doug, you talked about some of the net interest margin pressure coming from hedge ineffectiveness. Could you quantify of the 10 basis points how much you think that is? And do you expect that to revert in the third quarter? And then just generally, given the really oppressively low interest-rate environment that we're in right now, maybe some sense of your view on the net interest income trajectory of the company?

So on the first, it was several basis points of the impact. It's going to vary quarter on quarter, and it has varied quarter on quarter. So part of the difference this quarter is we had some positive results last quarter and negative results. The swing is what's reported from a NIM standpoint.

On the NII, in aggregate, we have some portfolio runoffs and we've been – we've provided you some guidance around that. We continue to build our balances and build our loan portfolios so the question is going to be which exceeds the other here.
And one disclosure you're going to see is that this AFS portfolio is yielding 2.6% but this quarter it's going to be -
2.47%. That is hedge ineffectiveness. It's really still yielding 2.6%. So it isn't that we did something like that, it's just that hedge ineffectiveness when it goes against the asset.

And then as a quick follow-up, you talked about potentially getting – being close to zero in terms of mortgage repurchase costs through – at least though the income statement over the next several quarters. Can you give us maybe a little more commentary around that? Are you seeing a significant decline in claims starting to come in? And then secondarily can you make any comments in terms of your sense of what's going on in the private label side of mortgage repurchases either in terms of claims or with respect to litigation?

Yeah, so the real differential, there has been a modest decline, the real differential is our cure rates. Because as these demands go deeper into the securities, they are taking more mortgages that have been paying for longer and the result of that is that we've been decreasing the amount of demands we actually have to repurchase. That's really been driving in part the analysis. On the private label side you will see in our supplement we had a modest increase in demand but much of that is going to make it's way through litigation.
So your statement about zero really excludes any thoughts about that litigation?
That's separate, separate and distinct.
Okay, thanks.
Chris Kotowski.

Yes. Also for Doug, I wonder if you could walk us through a little bit on the changes in the Basel III ratio. At the end of March you reported 8.4%, this is 7.9%. Obviously the NPR must have had an impact there and I was wondering if you could break down what the bigger chunks of that impact are. Is it the treatment of home equity loans or...?

Sure. Actually 20 basis points was refinement of our earnings as a function of the restatement so there was a move from the restatement, actually about 10 basis points. The remaining 30 basis points you can think about that principally as the CRM minimum that was added to the Basel 2.5 rules. That's the bulk of the RWA. It's an increase of about $40 billion for our portfolio. We would estimate, because that is subject to model approval and you need at least 12 months of operation model approval from the first quarter of 2013 so we're hopeful that $40 billion comes back into and it's included in some of those projections that Jamie showed you, coming back as reductions. So we were pretty close on our Basel III estimates.
Okay. Now the way I read it though in the home equity loans in particular it looked like for over 80% loan to values that you were going to have a 1.5 times capital charge -
That's Basel I.
Okay.
That's Basel I. Basel III rules didn't really change very much for the mortgage portfolio.
Okay. Great. Thank you.
Vince Breitenbach.

Hi. Thank you. I understand from your information that one of the reasons for the losses here was that perhaps the success of the unit led to some complacency in overall governance of the unit. And as I look through some of the discovery information it seems that the risk management profile here was one that excluded certain basic tenets of risk management, granular levels of asset, concentration risk, etcetera. So I guess that begs the question: was this unit ill-conceived from a risk management perspective from day one and it took five years to reach the end result or were there are perhaps some small successive lapses in credit management over time that ultimately, and perhaps we can look at the new VaR model as inadvertently being one of those, that ultimately led to this result?

So I would say it is something that the complexity of synthetic credit was there over five years and there were things that obviously we could have caught it sooner but it didn't, until the circumstances of the first quarter, get us. But the overall mistake was allowing something that wasn't like the rest of the ALM type of activities to get housed inside CIO that had one form of risk management structure and then put something new in that required a whole different type of risk wrapped around it and didn't do it at the time.
Todd Hagerman.

Yes. Good morning, Mike and Jamie. Mike you talked a lot about the VaR model and some of the changes. Jamie, you've talked in the past about your feelings one way or the other in terms of the usefulness of VaR, if you will. What I'm curious about is with all the discussion on VaR, if you will, what changes have been made in terms of the dependence on the models themselves and how that relates back to the risk management and the model group and what other control tools you may have put in place to again make this a more robust process if you will?

First of all, I don't run a business on models. If you do run a business on models, you will be dead. It doesn't work. VaR is one model. We use tons of other models, and I think Mike pointed out the right way to do it is have lots of other granular limits, notional amount limits, credit spread limits, single name limits, all these things. VaR is just one. VaR does not capture underlying changes in (1:39:34). It doesn't capture changes in correlations. It's only backward looking. So it's a data point that helps you manage your business, that's all it is. Now, having said that, Mike, we've got to do a better job implementing some of these models.

Right. It's the process of running (1:39:29) models, not the models themselves that is defining there. And the granular risk. Those are the two big takeaways if you look at the findings that I would say is get the right limits around the activity, one. That's not necessarily a VaR model or any one given type of activity, but if we're going to put things in, we've got to have belts and suspenders to make sure we're approve for the right reasons and have the right operational support around it.

Just as a follow-up, it's my understanding as an example with the CCAR process and the review of the trading operation specifically, a lot of the dependence was placed on the models in terms of that review. What are you sensing now in terms of given the event that has transpired, how that evaluation is going to change on a go-forward basis, particularly as we think about next year's CCAR process in light of this event?

I think we have certainly put a lot of attention on it ourselves, and I think that the takeaways that we saw was just bolstering all processes around model of governance, implementation, approval, a new team, we took a 25-year veteran risk manager in charge of a new group that's really going to lead up, watching model activities, all parts of the process. Because really the mistake we made here was roles and responsibilities.

So whereas I would say we are very good in particularly our Investment Bank, which is the heaviest user of models. We have got a very robust in-business market risk teams that have the handoff of dealing with parallel testing, back testing, running the operational model themselves. CIO is weaker in that regard. So when we have interaction between the independent model review group and the market risk teams in the business, again a particular mistake here. But that's a policy and procedure thing that we've tightened up, and John Hogan has done a lot in the past two months.

CCAR is not VaR dependent. It's stress testing. We do – I would say stress testing is more important than most of the other stuff. So we do extensive stress testing. And so to me, you've got to get that right. So CCAR has embedded in it is one test. We do 100s of stress tests, and obviously we should have done stress testing in this particular portfolio better too.
Paul Miller.

Thanks. Jamie, the 10-year today is right around 1.5. We keep on hoping as banking analysts that it keeps on going up, but every quarter it goes down. The ten-year, the flat year curve, which is really starting to weigh on a lot of people's net interest margins. Your net interest margin was down like 13 or 14 basis points. It really feels like this 10-year is not going to move and we're going to live with a flat yield curve longer than anybody wish, maybe in the 2014 or 2015. How do you as a bank position yourself for that environment, even if it goes down as a lot of people are thinking to 1% at this point?

I'm not talking about going down to 1%, but we are getting near the end of the margin compression from the yield curve. So if I remember correctly, about a year or two to go, we might lose another $400 million or $500 million. And then it flattens out. If the 10 goes down more, it's even more. We're short. Most banks have a much longer duration than we do. So we could easily today change what we are doing and put on $50 billion in mortgages at 3% and earn a lot more. If you really believe that, we could change our structure to earn back some of that income, and in fact far more than we might lose on the 10-year.

Take a bigger step back, if we're going to be living with this flat yield curve, banks like to live with a steep yield curve. That's what we've all been raised on for the last three or four decades, but if we are going to live in this environment, how do banks operate? How do you position your institution to go forward with a continued flat yield curve? You can adjust the balance sheet, that's a one-time issue, but going forward, how would you run this institution?

As I was telling you, I don't think – most of the effect of the yield curve has gone away. If it stays like this forever we're still going to earn about what we're earning. So it isn't like you have to deal with a negative every year after every year. It will – obviously how you do your loans and your deposits and a lot of things in our balance sheet which earn very little because we're almost doing it as a service to clients, you might do less of that. So you set up $200 billion of treasury assets we have we're earning five basis points on that. We don't need to keep those deposits that we may modify that but you will change your pricing, your products, your services to try to earn a fair return on capital.
Gerard Cassidy.
Gerard Cassidy, RBC Capital Markets. Doug you touched on the LCR ratio under Basel III do you guys have an estimate of where that is today? The liquidity ratio?

Yeah, we've, so basically, if you did the number today it might show a gap but that gap is easy for us to fix by just changing our asset mix. So we will be LCR compliant by reinvesting the AFS portfolio or doing a slight different things. We want to see the final rule before we start swinging the balance sheet all over the place. We'll be fine. We are a very liquid company.

And following up on the yield curve commentary that you just made Jamie. Are the returns acceptable? As you pointed out there is not any incremental negative impact for you guys if the yield curve stays this way, but are the returns on equity acceptable or would you try some other strategy, possibly shrinking the balance sheet and buying back even more stock?

We ask that question all the time but we're actually believe it or not getting good returns right now. When you look at the returns in our businesses, the 15% return in tangible equity, the record earnings, so could you do more? What we'd like to do is build the business. Bankers, services, clients, execution of services to grow our business over time and we have been doing that so that's what we focus on and we'll modify pricing, products and balance sheet to get a fair return.
And then finally, maybe your comments on what you are seeing in Europe and how they are progressing on solving some of those problems, do you want add any color to that?

It's very hard to add to the debate you read about it every day. You now are reading about what they kind of need to do and they need to do all of them. One of the banks have their European bank regulator or European bank scheme to stop bank runs, to have some facility that can finance the Italian and Spanish sovereign debt in the meantime and a fiscal union that people believe in. We figure to see that kind of in fits and starts over time. And just be prepared for the roller coaster.
Michael Liper.
Good morning, Jamie.

On those assets and 76 liabilities. Two questions. Can you tell us how much of those are netted from the same counterparty? And second, how much of those numbers was the CIO numbers in that at the end of that quarter?
We'll do the second one first. I think it is a very small – CIO is a very small part of that number.
Okay. I would agree.

And so that's number one. And number two, there are very complex lending rules, which I don't want to go through here, about derivatives but we did do a presentation at one point showing exactly how derivatives net by counterparty and we would be happy to share that with you and take you through it.
Thank you.
Yeah.

Let me make an announcement for the phone. If you are on the phone please put yourself on the queue at this point and we're going to take a few more questions in the room and then we're going to move to the phones.

Hi, Nancy Bush, again. Mike, a question for you. You know that's a good question, Nancy. Prior to that, there was obviously work being done with Senior risk folks, but looking through the lens of the CIO risk team. So it took it to a different level of intrusion.
The CIO risk team did an inadequate job.

One critique of the industry has always been the incentive structure. I'm just wondering if in the CIO review there was any conclusions based on if incentives were aligned with long-term shareholder interest?

Sure. Obviously we looked at all that. None of the people in CIO are on any form of formulas. The business is not on a formula. We obviously looked at compensation for what we were doing in CIO relative to what you would see pay related to running a $350 billion fixed income portfolio. I can't obviously get in the minds of the individuals that have been making individual decisions but we looked for evidence of particular things that were problematic around our compensation schemes and found no particular issues.

Yeah, first of all, as you know Investment Banking revenues are unpredictable by their nature. And whenever they come in with a low number, I would say, well it could be much higher. So right now it looks similar to what it was last quarter. That can change at any one point in time. Obviously I think you see everywhere business in Asia and Europe are down. America remains to be seen.

We share a lot of information with people who ask. The regulators are completely up-to-date on all of Mike's information, right? They've been through this several times.
Yes, absolutely, more than absolutely.
David Sochol.

Thank you. Dave Sochol, Levin Capital. Maybe from the perspective of a buy-sider and a long-suffering shareholder and my clients, I would like to follow-up on Mike Mayo's question and also reference a KBW report that looked at the potential of splitting off the Chase Consumer Bank with auto and credit and having a standalone JPMorgan commercial bank, Investment Bank, trust, and TSS and the point being not just the tipping point or actual diseconomies of scale and even if there are economies of scale, the stock market refuses to acknowledge it in terms of the multiple continuing to come down. I look at the track record over the past year or so and notwithstanding the great performance relative to a pretty low bar, but still a good performance, but we've had the mortgage servicing issues, mortgage foreclosure issues, the military veteran issues, energy, commodities, sales practices, now this inexcusable, just unbelievable CIO debacle, now potential LIBOR. And I think about what has to happen for you as a management team, or you as a board to finally say, we are a great institution and we own a lot of great businesses, but we have reached that point where we are too big to manage and in the interest of our shareholders, there is a different corporate structure that would better serve your owners? Thank you.

I beg to differ. Okay. There is huge strength in this company that the units get from each other. So we don't have the strategy that we're guessing at things. The Investment Bank or the Commercial Bank, the TSS gives huge order flow to the investment bank. We think there is an enormous amount of cross sell. And we do just as much as anybody else out there between the Consumer Bank, small business, private wealth management, credit card, mortgage. Our job is to do a great job serving clients, grow the business and eventually the stock will reflect it. And so I think also people splitting off companies, my whole life there's people who splits it off as a higher fee, lower fee, that's very short-term stuff. Have a strategy, execute on it, build the business, that's how you build value. We don't feel great that we haven't done a great job for shareholders recently. That we completely acknowledge. But we're going to keep on building the company and one day the stock will reflect it. If the board ever thought there were better strategies then that will be considered at the time.

Right. I would respectfully say that certainly the cross sell is very obvious and that's why I would not look at separating it into numerous companies. But I'm just wondering at what point it does become more apparent that there are diseconomies and is there potential that – is it possible that had CIO been part of a smaller institution it would have gotten the management look that it required?
Hundreds of small banks have gone bankrupt. Okay. Monolines went bankrupt.
I'm not comparing you with those.

You could argue the other way. There's a huge source of strength in how strong this company is through all these storms, can do Bear Stearns and WaMu, do all these wonderful things. CIO was a mistake and we're sorry.

Jamie, quick follow-up on sort of your perspective on capital. A little bit and you know what those things are. It's Europe, the fiscal cliff in the United States, it's all those things that make you be a little more cautious. But again, I think we're going to earn money next year regardless of those things, whatever happens.
Gerard Cassidy.

Mike, you gave us a very thorough, detailed disclosure on how you attacked this problem with the CIO and you're very confident that you have your arms around it. I can't speak for the regulators. But certainly they've been – we've spent a lot of time with them to keep them informed and obviously wanted to guide our work from the get-go in a way that was going to satisfy a lot of different constituencies.

They're going to do their own work as they should and come to their own conclusions. Remember the board, as an independent group, are still guiding this task force and will come to its own conclusions too.
Brennan Hawken.

Mike, when you went through your review, do you think that maybe the idea that there was no formula for comp in CIO might have led to some of the trouble and the stretching? And then on a go-forward basis, as the follow-up, which is probably more important, how are you guys thinking about structuring comp in the CIO office over the next few years?

No. I don't think – when we talk about formulas, individuals getting a cut of revenue, none of that existed, and I don't think that's a good thing. I think the kind of practices that are common in CIO are the same as what we do in our investment bank, it's taking the totality of managers' subjective judgment of performance and a multiyear view of how good a person is in a job over multiple years. All that together with the pay practices of how we defer compensation, all are sound policies and it's the application, obviously, that you have to get right. Matt, who is now running CIO, I'm sure will just bring his own individual management style into doing that, but we didn't walk away with the feeling that there was anything different about that unit of the company or that the company broadly should be doing differently around administering compensation.

And the idea now that we don't have synthetic in CIO, clearly that's going to mean we should probably just assume more volatile results out of that business, particularly in times when credit is getting a little funky?
No, no.
Obviously with the recent quarter as an exception.

I showed the portfolio, AA plus. It's an AFS portfolio. It's not marked-to-market in the P&L. It's got a 3.7 year average life, 80% government, government guaranteed or government type of entity guaranteed. You're not going to have more volatility in it.

If we have a small hedge there, if we are so – and you see we hedge more in Europe, that's why we need the ability to hedge. But really it has very little to do with AFS. AFS is subordinate to the rest of the company. Nothing would please us more than to reduce AFS and make some more great loans. So they can't say, be paid just on the revenues and their profits, because they're not there for that. They are there to manage this portfolio. We need some very good people. It's $350 billion. It operates, I forgot, out of how many countries under multiple currencies, so it is – we need some very good people managing that book, just like we would at PIMCO or BlackRock, big fixed income portfolio.

So our expectation is we had thought we would see more movement in the second, third and fourth quarter. It's more likely that's a 2013 event.
